subclassFeature.name: College of Angst
entries: {@i Wake Me Up Inside (Can't Wake Up)}

Bards of the College of Angst claim to harbour a deep emptiness in their soul, which they channel into dreary expressions of dark despair. Wielding profound power over emotions, their performances inspire rebellion in their allies and drown their foes in misery. Forever misunderstood, these Bards broadcast their agony for all to hear.

subclassFeature.name: Dabbler in Dark Magics
entries: Your dark feelings have granted you even darker magic. Enchantment and Necromancy spells from the Warlock spell list are added to the Bard spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Tormented Muse
entries: Whenever you give an ally a Bardic Inspiration die, your performance stirs a deeply held dark emotion from it. When the ally uses the Bardic Inspiration die, the emotion bursts forth and provides an additional effect, based on whether the die benefits an ability check, attack roll or saving throw.

entries.name: Anger (attack roll)
entries: Immediately after the attack roll, the target of the attack must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or have the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of the attacker's next turn. The attacker is the source of the fear.

entries.name: Fear (saving throw)
entries: The ally's fear flares and makes it more wary of its situation. It adds the result of the die roll to its AC until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Sorrow (ability check)
entries: The ally's sorrow wells up, creating an emotional barrier. It gains {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled on the Bardic Inspiration die plus your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: If Misery is Contagious Then Let Me Be Your Plague
entries: As a Magic action, you can begin a performance, laced with dour magic which leaves its listeners mired in angst. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 3+ spell slot (no action required).

entries.name: Inspire Angst
entries: When you start the performance, and as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on your subsequent turns, you can force a number of creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum 1) that can see or hear you and are within 30 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, a creature gains one level of Angst, to a maximum of 3. Refer to the Angst Effects table to determine the effects on the creature, which are cumulative with each added level.
You can use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} as part of the same {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} you use to grant an ally a Bardic Inspiration die.

entries.name: Duration
entries: The performance lasts for a maximum of 1 minute. It ends early if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition, or choose to end it early (no action required).

entries.name: Ending the Effect
entries: An affected creature can repeat the Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns, reducing its level of Angst by 1 on a success. If a creature succeeds on its initial save, or otherwise reduces its level of Angst to 0, it automatically succeeds on all subsequent saving throws it makes against this performance.
An affected creature automatically loses all levels of Angst when the performance ends, or if it is affected by the {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} or {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} spells.

entries.name: Angst Effects
rows: 1 - The creature begins to feel the weight of its emotion pull it down.
The target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks.
2 - The creature is overwhelmed by its dark emotions.
The target can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}, and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls.
3 - The creature is despondent. It can do little more than brood.
The target has the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Not Just a Phase
entries: Your misery festers, twisting into dreadful might. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Crippling Angst
entries: If a creature fails its saving throw against your Inspire Angst by 5 or more, it gains two levels of Angst, instead of one.

entries.name: I'm (Not) Okay
entries: When you become {@condition Bloodied|XPHB} or gain the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition, you can empower your performances with the pain of your current existence. For the next minute, your spell save DC increases by 2 and whenever a creature rolls one of your Bardic Inspiration dice, it can add 2 to the roll's total.
Once you use this benefit, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: College of Vanity
entries: {@i Obsess in your Incredible Self}

Bards of the College of Vanity value nothing more than the admiration of their perfect selves; admiration from others, but also themselves. These self-interested bards brave the risks of adventuring for a shot at attaining glory and recognition. Not to mention, it would be a crime to not share that face with the world.

subclassFeature.name: Self-Interested
entries: You are easily distracted by reflections of yourself, your shadow, or even thoughts about yourself. You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} you make to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition, and any save that requires you to see an effect to be affected by it, such as a Medusa's Gaze.

subclassFeature.name: Vain Inspiration
entries: When you use your Bardic Inspiration feature to inspire an ally, you get caught up in your own hype and also inspire yourself. The Bardic Inspiration die you grant yourself is a {@dice d4}. The feature otherwise benefits you as it would any other creature.
The size of the die you grant yourself increases when you reach certain levels in this class: {@dice 1d6} at level 10 and {@dice 1d8} at level 15.

subclassFeature.name: Center of Attention
entries: As a Magic action, you can attempt to force those around you to pay attention to you. Each creature of your choice within 30 feet of yourself must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, a creature has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. While it is {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls, Wisdom checks and Charisma checks made to engage, observe, or otherwise deal with creatures other than you. An affected creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. The effect ends early for all targets if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition, or if you use this feature again.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can restore the use of this feature by expending a level 3+ spell slot (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Inflated Confidence
entries: When you roll a Bardic Inspiration die granted to you by your Vain Inspiration and it causes you to succeed on a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, your own success inspires you further, causing the die to not be spent. You can retain a die in this way no more than once per use of your Bardic Inspiration feature.

subclassFeature.name: College of Mime
entries: {@i Work Magical Wonders in Silent Performances}

Bards of this college put together precise and practiced silent routines, patomiming the presence of nonexistent entities. The secret that these bards hold, however, is that they have learned to mime objects and beings into existence, creating unexpected invisible entities which they can use both artistically and offensively.

subclassFeature.name: Pantomime Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to incorporate your spells into your silent act. Whenever you cast a Bard spell, you can ignore any Verbal or Material components that aren't costly or consumed. When you do so, you must perform a Somatic component for the spell, even if it doesn't usually have one, usually in the form of a mime routine.

When you cast a spell in this way, you can attempt to obscure the fact that you are casting a spell. Creatures that can see you when you cast the spell can make a Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check against your spell save DC, understanding that you cast a spell on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Invisible Shield
entries: You gain the ability to develop an invisible shield-like force field to ward off incoming attacks. When you or a creature within 10 feet of you takes damage, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to roll and expend a Bardic Inspiration die to create a shield. The shield has a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to two times the number rolled, and takes damage instead of the target. The shield lasts until the end of the current turn, or until it runs out of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, at which point it audibly shatters and any damage not absorbed by the shield carries over to the target.

subclassFeature.name: Mime Routines
entries: By infusing magic into your pantomime act, you can produce special effects that allow you to seemingly break the laws of physics. You learn the following acts:

entries.name: Defy Gravity
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you grant yourself a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to half your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} and can hover for 1 minute, as you climb non-existent objects, swim through air, or some other amusing act.

entries.name: Invisible Box
entries: As a Magic action, you attempt to trap a creature within 5 feet of you inside an {@condition invisible} box of magical force. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or be trapped in the box. While trapped, the creature has {@variantrule Cover|XPHB|Total Cover} and is unable to Move. The box is an object with AC equal to 12 + your Charisma modifier, and a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your Bard level. The box vanishes after 1 minute, or when it drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Sudden Gust
entries: As a Magic action, an apparent strong gust of wind emerges from your space in a 50 foot long, 10 foot wide {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line}. Each creature of your choice in that area (potentially including yourself) must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be pushed 30 feet in the wind's direction.
You can use one of these acts a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum once), and regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Unseen Spells
entries: You gain the ability to fold your spells into your pantomime routine. When you use your Pantomime Spellcasting feature, you can choose to make the spell's effects {@condition Invisible|XPHB} to creatures without {@sense Truesight|XPHB}, resulting in the following effects:

items.name: Unseen Hazards
entries: Creatures that cannot see the spell subtract {@dice 1d4} from any saving throw they make to avoid or resist it.

items.name: Unseen Strike
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any attack roll you make with the spell against a creature that cannot see it.

items.name: Unseen Summons
entries: Any creature or object summoned by the spell has the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition for the spell's duration. An {@condition Invisible|XPHB} creature must roll {@dice 1d4} at the end of any turn on which they made an attack or cast a spell. On a roll of 1, the condition ends on it.

If the spell has no visual elements to begin with, then using this feature confers no benefit. Furthermore, if the spell only affects targets that see its effects, such as with {@spell Hypnotic Pattern|XPHB}, then any creature without {@sense Truesight|XPHB} is unaffected by the spell.
Once you cast a spell in this way, you cannot do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Vitamancer
entries: {@i Manipulate the Energy of Life}

You have studied to inner workings of life, and can use this knowledge to bend vital energy to your will. While they lack the divine power to cast healing spells, Vitam-ancers use their power to augment their allies, summon forth new life and to rend vitality from their foes.

subclassFeature.name: Vitality Magic
entries: Your studies have revealed the intrinsic mechanisms of life in all of its forms. You have proficiency with the {@skill Medicine|XPHB} and {@skill Nature|XPHB} skills. If you already have either proficiency, you instead gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in it.

Also, certain spells are added to the Wizard spell list for you, listed in the Vitality Spells table. When you gain this feature, and again whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class, you can add one of these spells to your spellbook for free. The chosen spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Manipulate Vitality
entries: You can manipulate the forces of life by drawing energy from living creatures, using Vitality Dice, which are d6s.

items.name: Number of Dice
entries: You can harbor a number of Vitality Dice up to your Wizard level. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you have an amount equal to half your Wizard level (round up), regardless of how many you had before the rest.

items.name: Spending Limit
entries: The maximum number of Vitality Dice you can spend on a single effect equals your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.

items.name: Capture Lost Life
entries: When you cast a spell with a spell slot, you can capture any lost life it causes. The first time that the spell deals damage to a creature, you gain one Vitality Die. If the spell targets a friendly creature or summons one, you instead gain the dice the first time that creature deals damage to another creature, provided you are {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating} on the spell.
You can spend Vitality Dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Amplify Harm
entries: When you deal damage to a creature with a Wizard spell, you can spend Vitality Dice to deal extra Necrotic damage to one of the spell's targets equal to one roll of the dice. You cannot use Capture Lost Life when you use this feature.

entries.name: Transfer Life
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can spend Vitality Dice to heal one creature you can see within 60 feet of you. The target regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to one roll of the expended dice.

subclassFeature.name: Life Link
entries: When you cast a spell that requires {@status Concentration|XPHB}, you can link your vitality with that of one willing creature affected by the spell. Until the spell ends on the selected creature, whenever either of you takes damage or regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to negate that damage or healing and cause the unaffected creature to take it instead. This damage bypasses {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

subclassFeature.name: Instill Resilience
entries: When you use your Transfer Life feature and spend at least 3 Vitality Dice to heal a creature, that creature's vitality is temporarily protected. Until the start of your next turn, the target has {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to all damage and its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum can't be reduced.

subclassFeature.name: Vital Surge
entries: When you use either your Amplify Harm or Transfer Life feature, you can augment the effect by drawing on ambient vital energy. When you do, the Vitality Dice become d12s, and the feature gains an extra effect:

entries.name: Amplify Harm
entries: Each target of the spell cannot regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Transfer Life
entries: You can target more than one creature with the effect, spending Vitality Dice on each target separately. The total number of Vitality Dice you spend can exceed your Spending Limit, but you can't spend more than your limit on any single creature.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
